Sentence: Bathsheba travels to Bath to warn Troy of Boldwood's anger, and while she (Fanny) is there, Troy convinces her (Fanny) to marry him (Troy)
A few weeks after his (Gabriel) marriage to Bathsheba, Troy sees Fanny, poor and sick; she (Fanny) later dies giving birth to her (Fanny) child
Grief-stricken at Fanny's death and riddled with shame, Troy runs away and is thought to have drowned
Boldwood holds a Christmas, to which he (Troy) invites Bathsheba and again proposes marriage; just after she (Fanny) has agreed, Troy arrives to claim her (Fanny)
